caseTitle: DAASEBRE NANA OSEI BONSU II ALIASSWALD GYIMAH-KESSIE] v AKW
summary: The Supreme Court of Ghana, in a judgment delivered on 24th February 2010, allowed the appeal brought by Akwasi Mensah, Ben Ephson, The Daily Dispatch, and Allied News Limited against Daasebre Nana Osei Bonsu II. The case arose from a 2003 article titled 'Mamponghene in 264 million cedis fraud,' which reported on a petition alleging the respondent received money for nominating a queen mother. The High Court had dismissed the libel claim, but the Court of Appeal reversed that decision, awarding damages. The Supreme Court reinstated the High Court’s judgment, holding that the publication constituted fair comment on a matter of public interest. The Court found that the appellants did not act maliciously and that the subject matter—concerning a traditional leader—was inherently of public concern. It emphasized that customary dispute resolution mechanisms, such as those led by the Asantehene, are valid and their proceedings may be reported. The appeal was deemed properly constituted despite a technical error in naming the court in the notice of appeal.

rationaleHighlights: The publication was held to be fair comment on a matter of public interest.
The respondent, as a traditional leader, was a public figure whose conduct was subject to public scrutiny.
The petition to the Asantehene placed the facts in the public domain, supporting the defence of fair comment.
The appellants were found not to have acted maliciously in publishing the article.
The 'rolled-up plea' in pleadings has become obsolete under current civil procedure rules.
Customary dispute resolution mechanisms are recognized and may be reported in the public interest.
Technical errors in the notice of appeal do not invalidate the appeal if substantial justice is served.
The headline and opening paragraph were deemed comment, not assertion of fact.
